title: A Case of Chronic Knee Pain in a Middle-Aged Athlete
clinical_history: Meet Sarah, a 45-year-old recreational runner and tennis player who has been experiencing knee pain for the past 6 months. The pain started gradually, with no specific incident or trauma, and has been worsening over time. She reports that the pain is mainly located in the anterior and medial aspects of her knee, which worsens with activities such as running, squatting, and climbing stairs. She also experiences stiffness and swelling in the knee, particularly after prolonged periods of inactivity or at the end of the day.

nprs.affected_area: Anterior knee pain, medial knee pain

aggrevating_factors: Running, squatting, climbing stairs, jumping, and landing from jumps. Prolonged sitting or standing also exacerbates the pain.
picture: A 24-hour pain profile showing increased pain during and after activities, with some relief with rest and ice.
easing_factors: Rest, ice, and over-the-counter pain medications such as ibuprofen provide temporary relief.
past_history: Sarah has a history of Osgood-Schlatter disease as an adolescent and has had occasional knee pain with intense physical activity in the past. She has not had any previous knee injuries or surgeries.
medical_history: Generally healthy, with well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
medications: Ibuprofen as needed for pain and inflammation
personal_history: Married with two children, works as a marketing manager, and has a busy schedule with work and family commitments. She has had to reduce her physical activity level over the past year due to increasing knee pain.
imaging: X-rays of the knee show mild medial compartment narrowing and patellofemoral joint space narrowing. MRI shows no significant ligamentous or meniscal tears.
